resource.chars:
<u>wch is ash-coloured Ground-liver-wort & black pepper<\u>:
the manner of giving it not only to Men 
but to Dogs & cattle being accurately set 
down in the abovementioned number 237 of 
these Transactions, in a letter from Mr. Geo.
Dampier, dated Exmouth Nov.10.1697. to his 
Brother Capt.Wm. Dampier the famous sailor.
I must refer such as have occasion to give it, to that 
paper. Thus I hope yt <u>certain cures <\u> are discoverd 
for only two sorts of <u>Venomous Bites <\u> of Ani-
mals to <u>wch <\u> the happy soil of Great 
Britain exposes its Inhabitants.
I shall only beg leave to add a proposal of my own 
<u>wch <\u> I made in my <u>Thes. Inaugur. de Ingressu Hu-
morum in corpus humanum Lugd. Bat.<\u> 1724. that 
the use of ye hot bath, for <s>setting <\s> persons bit 
by a mad Dog, or <s>the setting them up to the 
chin in warm water, wch might <\s> hot fomentations might be of greater service than cold applications. For a cold Bath 
shutts ye pores, as a warm one opens them, therefore 
the blood being <s>certainly<\s> allowed to be greatly inflamed in this case 
& <u>Dampier’s powder <\u> being a very hot Medicine, It is 
reasonable to think yt <s>after <\s> when a patient hath taken it 
the setting him up to the chin in hot water for some 
hours, would help the operation of ye <u>Powders <\u>, by diluting 
the blood & relaxing ye pores.
